creator: eseidel@apple.com
text:
The charset 
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html;charset=big5">
is missing from index.html.zh-tw.big5

without it, the content does not display correctly in some (maybe all) browsers.

This is the default page installed by Apache.

A simple one line change is to add this tag.

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
This tag should not be necessary, and should in fact be ignored by browsers
who access the file through the server.  The content-type should come
from the HTTP headers, not the HTML.

Is there a specific problem you are seeing?

For one, not all requests for that page go through the server... some of our users like to view the 
documentation offline, so that tag makes sense in that case.  (Yes, I know the links break in that 
situation and all kinds of other nastyness... I have a bug in my queue to deal with that.)

Second, and more importantly, I'm not certain that it works even through the server... at least not 
through Safari.  That may be a bug in Safari...   I don't speak chinese, but I had this bug reported to 
me, and then walked down the hall to someone who does speak chineese and was able to 
reproduce it.   I'm not sure if we connected through the server or if we dropped the page into a 
browser directly.  The simple one line change fixed our problem... It seems to me to be "good 
form" for a website to carry a content meta tag even if the server also uses content type.

Third, all the other index.* pages have a meta tag, why not this one?

Further thoughts?
creator: eseidel@apple.com

text:
1. I can't really see any reason at all to view this page directly
through the filesystem.  It is a test page to tell if the server worked.
Viewing it few the file system tells you nothing.  In fact, things are clearer
if it doesn't work.

2. Adding that tag may simply hide some other problem.  If you can't see the
page properly through the server, then the problem causing that should be
addressed, not worked-around.  For example, it may be that Safari is being
case-sensitive, since the type-map file designates this file as
Content-type: text/html;charset=Big5
I'm not sure what is proper, but if there is a problem, it should be fixed.
It could also be that your apache install has an out-of-date or incorrect
type-map or config-file setting.

3. These test pages are just an irrelevant annoyance anyway.  They should
probably all be removed, since they cause much more trouble than they
are worth.
creator: slive@apache.org
slive@apache.org
text: I think I'll officially pass on this.  But thanks for the suggestion.
